section_path: Enhanced properties of LiFePO_{4}/C cathode materials modified by CePO_{4} nanoparticles
Article history: Received 5 January 2014 Received in revised form 28 April 2014 Accepted 5 May 2014

sentences.text: Owing to its advantages of low cost, nontoxicity, good cycle stability and a relatively high theoretical specific capacity (170 mAh g^{-1}), LFP (LiFePO_{4}) has drawn attentions as a potential cathode material for lithium-ion batteries since the pioneering works by Goodenough and his co-workers [1].
However, LFP has drawbacks such as low electronic conductivity and lithium-ion diffusion coefficient due to its intrinsic characteristics, which limits its application.
In recent years, many attempts have been made to improve the performance of LFP, including optimizing the particle size [2–4], coating conductive additives [5–7] and metal ions doping [8,9].
The reduced particle size can shorten the diffusion distance of lithium-ions.
increase the electronic conductivity between particles and metal ions doping can increase the diffusion coefficient of lithium-ions within the particle.
Several synthesis methods have been reported to obtain LFP with fine particle size, including co-precipitation [10], sol—gel [11], hydrothermal method [12,13] and other novel methods [14,15].
In this paper, we employed a hydrothermal method to synthesize LFP, which has been proved to be easy, fast, and cheap [12].
CePO_{4} coating has been found effective to suppresses Co dissolution and improve capacity retention of LiCoO_{2} cathode [16], and FePO_{4} coating also has great effects on olivine family [17,18].

Inspired by this idea, we successfully synthesized LiFePO_{4}/C/CePO_{4} (LFP/C/CPO) composite materials for the first time, and further prove that the existence of CePO_{4} introduced by in situ method can reduce the particle size of LiFePO_{4} significantly.
But the mechanism is different from the effects of La doping as we reported before [19], in which a solid solution was synthesized.
E-mail address: tzl@tsinghua.edu.cn (Z. Tang).
The sample of LFP/C was prepared by hydrothermal method derived from Nakano, H., et al.
The raw materials were LiOH·H_{2}O, FeSO_{4}·7H_{2}O, H_{3}PO_{4} (85 wt%) and ascorbic acid, which were used as Li.
P. and C sources, respectively.
All reagents were analytical grade (supplied by Beijing Chemical Reagent Ltd., China) and used as received without further purification.
The molar ratio of the Li:Fe:P:ascorbic acid was 3:1:1:0.2.
The concentration of  $FeSO_4$  in the precursor solution was 0.5 mol  $dm^{-3}$  and PH was 7.
Li source and P source were dissolved into deionized water under magnetic stirring for 30 min, and a mass of sticky mixture was formed.
Then, FeSO_{4} and ascorbic acid aqueous solution was added slowly with continuous stirring.
In order to prohibit the oxidation of Fe^{2+} to Fe^{3+}, the water was degassed by N_{2} gas bubbling for 30 min prior to preparing the solution.

80 ml of the precursor solution was sealed into a Teflon vessel (inner volume: 100 ml) coated in a stainless steel autoclave, and the reactor was heating at 190 °C in an oven for 12 h. The precipitated powder was collected by filtration and washed thoroughly with DI water and acetone.
The obtained powder was dried at 65 °C for 4 h under vacuum condition.
To increase the electrical conductivity of the carbon layer, the precipitated powder was heat-treated at 700 °C for 1 h, under a flow of Ar atmosphere containing 3 vol% H_{2}.
LFP/C/CPO samples were prepared with the same procedures as above.
Ce(NO_{3}) $_3$ ·3H $_2$ O was used as precursor, and the molar ratio of the Li:Fe:Ce:P:ascorbic acid was 3:0.99:0.01:1:0.2.
We name LFP/C and LFP/C/CPO sample a and sample b, respectively.
Crystallographic structures of the as-prepared materials were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Cu K $\alpha$ , D/max-V2500, Rigaku, Japan) from 10° to 80° (2 $\theta$ ) at 8° min^{-1}.
The morphology of the samples was studied by scanning electron microscope (SEM, LEO-1530, ZEISS, Germany).
The microstructure of the sample was examined using transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM 2100, JEOL, Japan) equipped with energy dispersive spectroscope (EDS).
The charge-discharge tests for the prepared samples were conducted using 2032 coin-type cells.

The composite cathode with thickness of about 40 µm was prepared by mixing the electrode composites with acetylene black and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) in n-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) in a weight ratio of 75:15:10.
The obtained viscous fluid was cast on aluminum foil and dried at 120 °C in vacuum overnight.
Then the composite electrode containing about 3 mg cm^{-2} of active material was cut into a circular shape (diameter 12 mm).
A lithium foil was used as the anode of the cell.
The electrolyte was a solvent mixture of ethylene carbonate (EC) and diethyl carbonate (DEC) in a volume ratio of 1:1 containing 1 M LiPF_{6}.
A porous polyethylene film (Celgard 2400, Celgard Ltd., USA) was used as a separator.
The cell was assembled in an argon-filled glove box.

Charge-discharge capacities were measured with the LAND batteries test system (CT2001A, Jinnuo Electronics Co., Ltd., Wuhan, China) in a voltage range of 2.4–4.2 V, under different current densities at room temperature.
The cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were conducted by an electrochemical workstation (CHI604B Shanghai Chenhua Co. Ltd., China).
CV tests were run at 0.1 mV s $^{-1}$  between 2 and 4.2 V, and EIS measurements were operated in the frequency range of 100 kHz to
All the EIS data were collected after the cells were discharged to 2.4~V at 1 C.
1 shows the XRD pattern of LFP/C and LFP/C/CPO.

sentences.text: 4 shows the initial chargeedischarge curves of LFP/C and LFP/C/CPO at 0.1 C (17 mA g^{1} ).
Both of the two samples exhibit very flat chargeedischarge plateaus.
It can be seen clearly from the results that CePO4 particles can improve the rate capacity of LFP/C.
The specific discharge capacity of LFP/C/CPO at a specific discharge current of 17 mA g^{1} is 156 mAh g^{1} , higher than that of LiFePO4/C (146 mAh g^{1} ).
The initial chargeedischarge curves of LFP/C/CPO at different specific discharge currents are shown in [Fig.
Although the rate capability of LFP/C/CPO was not so high as reported by other studies [\[13\],](#page-5-0) the role of CePO4 in improving the properties was undoubtedly demonstrated.
6](#page-3-0) shows the cycling performance of LFP/C and LFP/C/CPO at the discharge current of 1 C. Obviously, CePO4 modification can help to obtain a longer cycle life of LiFePO4.
The capacity retention of LFP/C/CPO is (about 97%) higher than that of LFP/C (about 93%).
The testing results above have shown good capacity and cycling properties of LFP/C/CPO.
The improvements can be attributed to four aspects.
Firstly, the enlarged contact area between electrodes and electrolytes caused by decreased particle size can improve the rate capacities.

Secondly, the electrode resistance will be decreased because of the decreased particle size, according to the empirical law: R^{m} f d^{n} (R^{m} represents the resistance of electrodes; d represents the particle size), put forward by Miran Gaberscek [\[21\].

](#page-5-0) Thirdly, CePO4 as an ionic conductor with stable structure can protect the electrodes from the corrosion of electrolytes like preformed SEI, which can reduce side reactions and improve the structure and cycling stability.

Fourthly, embedded CePO4 particles may make stronger connections between LFP particles to reduce and buffer volume change during lithiation and delithiation, which also contributes to the structure stability.

As for the formation of SEI, it is undoubted that different materials have different effects on the formation of SEI, even for the same material, different surface facets may also have different catalysis effects [\[22\].
](#page-5-0) So, CePO4 may also act as catalysts for the
Initial chargeedischarge curves at a specific discharge current of 17 mA g^{1} for LFP/C and LFP/C/CPO.
Initial chargeedischarge curves of LFP/C/CPO at a specific discharge current of 17, 85, 170, 340, and 850 mA g^{1} , respectively.
formation of SEI or is facilitating the formation of stable LiF rather than porous unstable Li2CO3, but it is needed further investigation.
Furthermore, there is a controversial viewpoint about the role of CePO4, that whether it could also storage energy.
CePO4, as for now, has not been reported as one typical energy storage material but proved to be an ionic conductor with stable structure in electrolytes [\[16\].
4](#page-2-0) and 5, we can see that there is only one pair of charge/discharge platforms, which implies that CePO4 does not contribute greatly to the specific capacitance.
Even if it has such property, the capacity contribution is believed to be negligible as the amount is so small.
The relative research should be carried out further.
The effects of CePO4 modification on the electrochemical performance of LFP/C can be further investigated by CV curves.

7 illustrates the CV profiles of LFP/C and LFP/C/CPO at the scan rate of 0.1 mV s^{1} between 2 and 4.2 V. The two samples both show similar CV curves with only one pair of redox peaks corresponding to a two phase reaction between lithiated phase LiFePO4 and delithiated phase FePO4.
It is noticed that the anodic and cathodic peak on CV curve of LFP/C/CPO is more symmetrical and sharper than that on CV curve of LFP/C, which clearly implies the enhancement
Plots of discharge capacity versus cycle number at room temperature from 1st to 50th cycle for LFP/C and LFP/C/CPO.
Cyclic voltammetry of LFP/C and LFP/C/CPO in the first cycle at the scan rate of 0.1 mV s^{1} between 2 and 4.2 V (vs. Li/Liþ).
of the lithium-ion diffusion ability.

In the case of LFP/C/CPO, the peak potential difference between anodic and cathodic peaks is 0.15 V, whereas in the case of LFP/C, it is 0.21 V. The well-defined peaks and the smaller peak potential difference on CV curve of LFP/C/CPO suggest that the reversibility of the electrode reaction of LFP/C/CPO is improved, and polarization is decreased, via CePO4 modification.
4 and 7,](#page-2-0) we discover that the difference between charge/discharge potential (which is also called over potential) is not obvious in [Fig.

As over potential is correlating to the inner resistance and polarization of electrodes during lithiation and delithiation [\[23\]](#page-5-0), this phenomenon may be caused by two aspects: Firstly, It is much more obvious as the current density is improved, because the charge exchange is not sufficient at larger current density, causing polarization.
So, when being tested at very small current density of 0.1 C, charge/discharge potential difference of the cells was not quite obvious, compared to CV tests.
Secondly, charge/discharged profile at 0.1 C represents the first cycle for electrodes after assembly, when SEI layer had not been formed completely.
This may also reduce the over potential effects caused by inner resistance.
However, when CV tests were performed after galvanostatic tests, SEI had already been formed completely.
Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy of the cells containing samples was measured to confirm the modification effect from the perspective of microscopic electrochemical kinetics.
EIS of LFP/C and LFP/C/CPO.
the Nyquist plots of LFP/C and LFP/C/CPO composite electrodes and its equivalent circuit.
In general, EIS is composed of two semicircles and a line inclined at a constant angle to the real axis.
The intercept impedance on the real axis corresponds to the solution resistance  $(R_s)$ .
The high-frequency semicircle represents the migration of the lithium-ions at the electrode/electrolyte interface through SEI layer.
The middle-frequency semicircle corresponds to the chargetransfer process  $(R_{ct})$ .
The slope in the low frequency region refers to the diffusion of the lithium-ions in the bulk material, which is also called Warburg-diffusion [24,25].
Generally speaking, the slope of the line in low frequencies refers to the diffuse ability of lithium ions in bulk material.
But the calculated diffusion coefficients ( $D_{Li}$ ) of this process further reveals the ability of lithium ions essentially, and reflects the effects of modification in quantity.

However, we could discover in our tests that there are two circles in the high-frequency region, one circle in the middle-frequency region, which is due to the effects of negative electrode, so we adopt the new equivalent circuit to simulate the data, in which  $R_1$  represents the charge-transfer resistance of lithium-ions corresponding to the negative electrode, R_{f} represents the impedance of SEI layer formed on the surface of the cathode [26].
The parameters of the equivalent circuit are listed in Table 1.

The lithium-ion diffusion coefficient ( $D_{\rm Li}$ ) of the as-prepared composites, which reflects the diffusion ability of lithium-ions in the bulk electrodes, can be calculated using the following expression (1) and (2) [27–29].
Exchange current density ( $i^0$ ) can be calculated using expression (3):
$$Z' = R_{\rm ct} + R_{\rm f} + R_{\rm 1} + R_{\rm s} + \sigma\omega^{-0.5} \tag{1}$$

where  $R_{\rm ct}$ : charge-transfer resistance of lithium-ions corresponding to cathode,  $R_{\rm f}$ : impedance of SEI layer formed on the surface of cathode,  $R_{\rm f}$ : charge-transfer resistance corresponding to anode,  $R_{\rm s}$ : electrolyte resistance,  $\omega$ : angular frequency in the low frequency region, D: diffusion coefficient, R: the gas constant, T: the absolute temperature, F: Faraday's constant, A: the area of the electrode surface, and C: molar concentration of lithium-ions (moles cm $^{-3}$ ),  $\sigma$ : the Warburg impedance coefficient.
The plot of Z' versus the reciprocal root square of the lower angular frequencies is illustrated in Fig.
The lithium-ion diffusion coefficients and exchange current densities for the two samples are also listed in Table 1.
Results prove that the charge transfer resistance of LFP/C/CPO (41.3  $\Omega$ ) is much smaller than that of LFP/C (81.1  $\Omega$ ), a remarkable decrease after CePO_{4} modification.
It is a common view that the charge transfer faradic process involves the diffusion of Li ions and conduction of electrons.

Much decreased particle size will improve the contact area between active particles and electrolytes, and shorten the diffuse distance of ions and electrons, which facilitate the charge transfer process.
Furthermore, according to the charge transfer model, reported by M. Gaberscek, particle size has key roles in decreasing the resistance of electrodes, facilitating the
**Table 1**Impedance parameters of the cells prepared from LFP/C and LFP/C/CPO.
** The relationship between Z' and  $\omega^{-0.5}$  at low frequencies.
So  $R_{\rm ct}$  is much smaller after modification.

Moreover,  $D_{\rm Li}$  is increased from  $1.22\times 10^{-13}~{\rm cm^2~S^{-1}}$  to  $2.56\times 10^{-12}~{\rm cm^2~S^{-1}}$ , indicating CePO_{4} modification enhances the ability of lithium-ion diffusion.
These results, in good agreement with the charge—discharge characteristics, confirm CePO_{4} modification can improve the electrochemical properties of LFP/C further.
We have proved the modification effects of CePO_{4} on LiFePO_{4} in the form of LiFePO_{4}/C/CePO_{4} composites.
CePO_{4} nanoparticles with the particle size of 10 nm are nailed on the surface of LiFePO_{4}.
Galvanostatic tests exhibit a significant improvement in rate capacities and cycle performance for LFP/C/CPO via CePO_{4} modification, compared with LFP/C.
CV and EIS measurements confirm further that LFP/C/CPO composites have better electrochemical properties than LFP/C.

From the results, the key roles of CePO_{4} nanoparticles can be summarized into two aspects: Firstly, nail effects: Introducing CePO_{4} with in situ method during the synthesis process can reduce particle size and combine LiFePO_{4} particles, making stronger connections to buffer volume change; Secondly, protection effects: CePO_{4} nanoparticles, as ionic conductor with stable structure in electrolytes, can protect electrodes from the corrosion of electrolytes like pre-formed SEI.
As a whole, CePO_{4} modification by in situ method is beneficial to improve the battery performance, but, the content effects should be further investigated to reveal its role.
